data.title: 100 Greatest Songs from 1982
data.meta_description: The year 1982 marked a turning point in the world of music. It was a year of creative explosion, with artists from various genres pushing boundaries and breaking new ground. data.meta_site_name: Singersroom.com - R&B Music, R&B Videos, R&B News
data.text:
The year 1982 marked a turning point in the world of music. It was a year of creative explosion, with artists from various genres pushing boundaries and breaking new ground. The 80s sound was in full swing, and the music industry was thriving. From pop to rock, from punk to hip hop, the music of 1982 left an indelible mark on the industry, and its legacy can still be felt today. In this article, we will explore the 100 greatest songs from 1982, highlighting the most memorable and influential tracks from that year.

From Michael Jackson’s iconic “Thriller” to Toto’s “Africa,” 1982 was filled with unforgettable hits that continue to resonate with audiences worldwide. Whether you were a fan of the synth-heavy sounds of the new wave or the catchy hooks of pop music, there was something for everyone in 1982. It was a year that saw the emergence of influential artists such as Prince, Madonna, and Duran Duran, who went on to become some of the most significant icons of the 80s.

In this article, we will delve into the stories behind the songs that defined 1982, exploring the artists’ inspirations and motivations behind their hits. We will also take a look at the impact these songs had on the music industry and their continued relevance in contemporary pop culture. Join us on a nostalgic journey back to 1982, as we celebrate the music that shaped a generation.

1. Physical – Olivia Newton-John

“Physical” is a pop song by Olivia Newton-John, released in 1981. The song features a catchy synth riff and energetic percussion that perfectly captures the upbeat, dance-oriented sound of the era. With lyrics that playfully reference fitness and exercise, the song became an instant hit, topping charts in multiple countries and earning Newton-John a Grammy nomination. The accompanying music video also helped cement the song’s popularity, featuring the singer performing energetic dance routines in a neon-lit gym. “Physical” remains a beloved classic of ’80s pop and an enduring symbol of the era’s upbeat, energetic spirit.

2. Eye of the Tiger – Survivor

“Eye of the Tiger” is a rock song by Survivor, released in 1982. The song was written specifically for the movie “Rocky III,” and its pounding rhythm and triumphant lyrics perfectly capture the film’s themes of perseverance and overcoming adversity. The song’s memorable opening guitar riff and powerful chorus have made it an enduring classic, and it has been used in countless movies, TV shows, and sports events over the years. “Eye of the Tiger” remains one of the most iconic and recognizable rock songs of all time, a testament to its enduring popularity and universal appeal.

3. I Love Rock ‘N Roll – Joan Jett and The Blackhearts

“I Love Rock ‘N Roll” is a rock song by Joan Jett and The Blackhearts, released in 1981. The song is a cover of a 1975 track by The Arrows, but Jett’s raw, energetic vocals and searing guitar riffs give it a distinctive punk edge. The song’s instantly recognizable opening guitar riff has become a staple of rock music, and its defiant lyrics and catchy chorus have made it a beloved classic. The accompanying music video, which features Jett performing in a small bar, perfectly captures the rebellious spirit of the song. “I Love Rock ‘N Roll” remains a beloved anthem of rock music and a testament to Jett’s enduring talent and influence.

4. Ebony & Ivory – Paul McCartney and Stevie Wonder

“Ebony & Ivory” is a duet by Paul McCartney and Stevie Wonder, released in 1982. The song uses the metaphor of a piano keyboard to explore themes of racial harmony and cooperation. McCartney’s upbeat pop melody and Wonder’s soulful vocals create a catchy and uplifting song that became an instant classic. The song’s accompanying music video, which features the two musicians playing piano in a colorful studio, perfectly captures the song’s positive message. “Ebony & Ivory” remains a beloved classic of ’80s pop and a testament to the power of music to bridge cultural divides.

5. Centerfold – The J. Geils Band

“Centerfold” is a new wave rock song by The J. Geils Band, released in 1981. The song features a driving guitar riff and catchy chorus that make it a quintessential party anthem. The song’s lyrics, which explore the idea of a former high school crush becoming a centerfold model, have been interpreted as both celebratory and cautionary. The song’s accompanying music video, which features the band performing in a neon-lit club, perfectly captures the song’s upbeat, high-energy spirit. “Centerfold” remains a beloved classic of ’80s rock and a testament to the enduring appeal of good-time party music.

6. Don’t You Want Me – The Human League

“Don’t You Want Me” is a synth-pop song by The Human League, released in 1981. The song features a pulsing electronic beat and catchy chorus that make it an enduring classic of ’80s pop. The song’s lyrics, which tell the story of a relationship falling apart, have been interpreted as both romantic and sinister. The song’s accompanying music video, which features the band performing in a club and intercut with scenes from a dramatic storyline, perfectly captures the song’s moody, atmospheric feel. “Don’t You Want Me” remains a beloved classic of ’80s synth-pop and a testament to the band’s unique style and vision.

7. Jack & Diane – John Cougar

“Jack & Diane” is a rock song by John Cougar (later known as John Mellencamp), released in 1982. The song tells the story of two young lovers in a small town, with a wistful melody and lyrics that capture the bittersweet feeling of young love. The song’s memorable chorus, which features the names of the two protagonists, has made it an enduring classic of ’80s rock. The song’s accompanying music video, which features Mellencamp performing in a bar and intercut with footage of young couples, perfectly captures the song’s nostalgic, romantic spirit.

8. Hurts So Good – John Cougar

“Hurts So Good” is a rock song by John Cougar (later known as John Mellencamp), released in 1982. The song features a pounding rhythm and catchy guitar riff that make it an instant classic of ’80s rock. The song’s lyrics explore the idea of love being both painful and pleasurable, and Mellencamp’s raspy vocals add a gritty edge to the song’s upbeat melody. The song’s accompanying music video, which features Mellencamp performing on a motorcycle and in a bar, perfectly captures the song’s rebellious, hard-driving spirit.

9. Abracadabra – Steve Miller Band

“Abracadabra” is a rock song by the Steve Miller Band, released in 1982. The song features a catchy synth riff and smooth vocals from Miller that make it a quintessential ’80s pop-rock hit. The song’s lyrics explore the idea of magic and attraction, with Miller’s smooth vocals adding a seductive edge to the song’s melodic hook. The song’s accompanying music video, which features the band performing in a colorful, surreal landscape, perfectly captures the song’s dreamlike, otherworldly feel. “Abracadabra” remains a beloved classic of ’80s pop and a testament to the enduring power of Steve Miller’s unique sound and style.

10. Hard to Say I’m Sorry – Chicago

“Hard to Say I’m Sorry” by Chicago is a classic soft rock ballad that explores the pain and regret of a broken relationship. The lyrics express a deep sense of remorse and a desire to make things right, but also an acknowledgement that it may be too late. The song features Chicago’s trademark blend of horns, keyboards, and guitar, creating a lush, melodic sound that perfectly complements the emotional content of the lyrics. With its memorable chorus and heartfelt vocals, “Hard to Say I’m Sorry” remains a beloved favorite among fans of ’80s pop rock.

11. Tainted Love – Soft Cell

“Tainted Love” by Soft Cell is a new wave classic that showcases the band’s unique blend of synthpop and post-punk. The song features a catchy synth hook and a driving beat, along with singer Marc Almond’s distinctive vocals, which convey a sense of longing and desperation. The lyrics describe a toxic relationship that has left the narrator feeling trapped and helpless. The song’s haunting melody and bittersweet lyrics have made it an enduring favorite among fans of ’80s music and beyond, and its influence can be heard in countless pop and electronic songs that followed.

12. Chariots Of Fire – Vangelis

“Chariots of Fire” by Vangelis is a soaring instrumental piece that has become synonymous with the triumph of the human spirit. The song’s iconic opening synthesizer riff and sweeping strings evoke a sense of grandeur and majesty, while its pulsing rhythm and percussion convey a sense of urgency and determination. Originally composed as the theme for the film of the same name, “Chariots of Fire” has become a beloved classic in its own right, inspiring countless athletes, musicians, and fans with its message of perseverance and triumph over adversity. Whether used as a theme for Olympic events or as background music in films and TV shows, “Chariots of Fire” remains a powerful and stirring musical work.

13. Harden My Heart – Quarterflash

“Harden My Heart” by Quarterflash is a classic rock song that features lead singer Rindy Ross’s soulful vocals and saxophone skills. The song’s driving beat and catchy guitar riffs create an energetic and memorable sound, while its lyrics express a sense of determination and resolve in the face of heartbreak. The chorus’s iconic refrain, “I’m gonna harden my heart, I’m gonna swallow my tears,” has become a favorite sing-along among fans of ’80s rock, and the song’s message of resilience and self-preservation continues to resonate with audiences today.

14. Rosanna – Toto

“Rosanna” by Toto is a pop-rock classic that showcases the band’s virtuosic musicianship and tight harmonies. The song’s infectious groove and catchy chorus have made it a perennial favorite on radio and in movies and TV shows, while its lyrics describe a love affair with a mysterious woman named Rosanna. With its mix of jazz, funk, and rock influences, “Rosanna” has become a defining track of the ’80s music scene, and continues to be celebrated for its catchy hooks and expert musicianship.

15. I Can’t Go for That (No Can Do) – Daryl Hall and John Oates

“I Can’t Go for That (No Can Do)” by Daryl Hall and John Oates is a smooth and funky R&B track that features the duo’s signature harmonies and soulful grooves. The song’s minimalist sound, featuring little more than a bassline, drum machine, and occasional keyboard riff, creates a hypnotic and irresistible groove that has become a hallmark of the ’80s sound. The song’s lyrics describe a reluctance to commit to a romantic relationship, and its memorable refrain, “I can’t go for that, no can do,” has become a favorite catchphrase of pop culture. With its timeless sound and catchy hooks, “I Can’t Go for That” remains a classic of the era.

16. 867-5309 / Jenny – Tommy Tutone

“867-5309/Jenny” is a classic rock song by Tommy Tutone. It tells the story of a man who sees a phone number written on a wall and decides to call it. He gets through to a woman named Jenny, and they start to have a conversation. The lyrics are catchy and the chorus is particularly memorable, with the repeated refrain of “867-5309/Jenny.” The song has become a cultural phenomenon and has been referenced in numerous TV shows, movies, and even a comic book series. It remains a beloved song that continues to be played on classic rock radio stations.

17. Key Largo – Bertie Higgins

“Key Largo” is a romantic ballad by Bertie Higgins that tells the story of a man who has lost the love of his life. He reminisces about their time together in Key Largo, a tropical paradise where they shared many happy moments. The song has a dreamy quality to it, with the soft melody and Higgins’ smooth vocals creating a sense of nostalgia and longing. “Key Largo” became a hit in the early 1980s and has since become a classic love song. It’s the perfect soundtrack for a lazy summer day or a quiet evening at home.

18. You Should Hear How She Talks About You – Melissa Manchester

“You Should Hear How She Talks About You” is an upbeat pop song by Melissa Manchester that celebrates the power of love. Manchester sings about a woman who has found a new love and can’t stop talking about him. The lyrics are playful and joyful, with Manchester’s vocals conveying a sense of excitement and happiness. The song has a catchy hook and a lively beat that make it perfect for dancing or singing along. “You Should Hear How She Talks About You” was a hit in the early 1980s and remains a popular song today.

19. Waiting for a Girl Like You – Foreigner

“Waiting for a Girl Like You” is a power ballad by Foreigner that expresses the yearning for true love. The song features soft piano notes, electric guitars, and Lou Gramm’s passionate vocals, creating a romantic and emotional atmosphere. The lyrics describe the feelings of a man who has been waiting for someone special to come into his life. The song became an instant hit when it was released in 1981 and is still widely regarded as one of the greatest love songs of all time.

20. Don’t Talk to Strangers – Rick Springfield

“Don’t Talk to Strangers” is a pop-rock song by Rick Springfield that warns of the dangers of talking to people you don’t know. The song features Springfield’s signature guitar riffs and edgy vocals, creating a catchy and upbeat tune. The lyrics warn listeners to be cautious when interacting with strangers, highlighting the importance of being aware of one’s surroundings. The song became a hit in 1982 and is still popular today, often played on classic rock stations.

21. The Sweetest Thing (I’ve Ever Known) – Juice Newton

“Don’t Talk to Strangers” is a pop-rock song by Rick Springfield that warns of the dangers of talking to people you don’t know. The song features Springfield’s signature guitar riffs and edgy vocals, creating a catchy and upbeat tune. The lyrics warn listeners to be cautious when interacting with strangers, highlighting the importance of being aware of one’s surroundings. The song became a hit in 1982 and is still popular today, often played on classic rock stations.

22. Always On My Mind – Willie Nelson

“Always On My Mind” is a classic country ballad by Willie Nelson that expresses regret over lost love. The song features Nelson’s signature vocals and acoustic guitar, creating a melancholy and emotional melody. The lyrics describe the feelings of a man who realizes too late how much he loved his partner and how he wishes he had treated her better. The song was released in 1982 and became a hit, earning Nelson a Grammy Award for Best Male Country Vocal Performance. It remains one of the most beloved country songs of all time and a testament to the power of regret and love.

23. Shake It Up – The Cars

“Shake It Up” is a new wave rock song by The Cars that celebrates the joy of dancing. The song features upbeat guitars, catchy synthesizers, and Ric Ocasek’s distinctive vocals, creating a lively and energetic tune. The lyrics encourage listeners to let loose and dance, describing the joy and freedom that comes with moving to the rhythm. The song was released in 1981 and became a hit, showcasing The Cars’ talent for creating catchy and memorable pop songs. It remains a beloved dance classic that still gets people moving on the dance floor.

24. Let It Whip – The Dazz Band

“Let It Whip” is a funk and R&B song by The Dazz Band that celebrates the joy of partying. The song features a groovy bassline, catchy horns, and Bobby Harris’ soulful vocals, creating a funky and infectious tune. The lyrics encourage listeners to let go and have fun, describing the freedom and joy that comes with letting loose. The song was released in 1982 and became a hit, earning The Dazz Band a Grammy Award for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals. It remains a beloved funk classic that gets people moving and grooving to this day.

25. We Got the Beat – The Go-Go’s

“We Got the Beat” is a new wave and power pop song by The Go-Go’s that celebrates the joy of music and dancing. The song features catchy guitar riffs, driving drums, and Belinda Carlisle’s energetic vocals, creating a lively and infectious tune. The lyrics describe the feeling of being swept up in the beat and the joy that comes with dancing. The song was released in 1981 and became a hit, earning The Go-Go’s a place in music history as the first all-female band to write their own songs and play their own instruments. It remains a beloved dance classic that still gets people moving on the dance floor.

26. The Other Woman – Ray Parker Jr.

“The Other Woman” is a soul and R&B song by Ray Parker Jr. that explores the complicated emotions surrounding infidelity. The song features Parker’s smooth vocals, melodic guitar riffs, and a groovy bassline, creating a mellow and contemplative melody. The lyrics describe the feelings of a man who is torn between two women and the pain and guilt that comes with cheating. The song was released in 1982 and became a hit, showcasing Parker’s talent for crafting emotional and soulful ballads. It remains a beloved R&B classic that captures the heartache of love and infidelity.

27. Turn Your Love Around – George Benson

“Turn Your Love Around” is a jazz-funk and R&B song by George Benson that celebrates the power of love to transform lives. The song features Benson’s smooth vocals, funky guitars, and catchy horns, creating a joyful and upbeat tune. The lyrics encourage listeners to open their hearts to love and let it change their lives, describing the transformation that comes with embracing love. The song was released in 1981 and became a hit, earning Benson a Grammy Award for Best R&B Vocal Performance, Male. It remains a beloved love song that captures the power of love to change lives for the better.

28. Sweet Dreams – Air Supply

“Sweet Dreams” is a soft rock and pop ballad by Air Supply that explores the bittersweet emotions surrounding a lost love. The song features Russell Hitchcock’s soaring vocals, Graham Russell’s delicate guitar work, and a lush orchestration, creating a romantic and melancholic melody. The lyrics describe the pain and longing that come with the end of a relationship and the dreamlike memories that remain. The song was released in 1982 and became a hit, showcasing Air Supply’s talent for crafting emotional and tender ballads. It remains a beloved love song that captures the heartache of lost love.

29. Only the Lonely – The Motels

“Only the Lonely” is a new wave and pop song by The Motels that explores the loneliness and isolation of modern life. The song features Martha Davis’s powerful vocals, Marty Jourard’s moody keyboards, and a driving beat, creating a dark and introspective melody. The lyrics describe the feeling of being alone in a crowded world and the yearning for connection and love. The song was released in 1982 and became a hit, showcasing The Motels’ talent for crafting moody and atmospheric pop songs. It remains a beloved new wave classic that captures the emotions of a generation.

30. Who Can It Be Now? – Men At Work

“Who Can It Be Now?” is a new wave and rock song by Men at Work that explores the paranoia and fear of modern life. The song features Colin Hay’s distinctive vocals, Greg Ham’s catchy saxophone riff, and a driving beat, creating a tense and suspenseful melody. The lyrics describe the feeling of being watched and the fear of unknown intruders, capturing the anxieties of a society on edge. The song was released in 1981 and became a hit, showcasing Men at Work’s talent for crafting catchy and intelligent pop songs. It remains a beloved new wave classic that captures the spirit of the times.

31. Hold Me – Fleetwood Mac

“Hold Me” is a soft rock and pop song by Fleetwood Mac that explores the complexities of love and relationships. The song features Christine McVie’s soothing vocals, Lindsey Buckingham’s intricate guitar work, and a catchy chorus, creating a warm and melodic melody. The lyrics describe the push and pull of a relationship and the need for love and connection. The song was released in 1982 and became a hit, showcasing Fleetwood Mac’s talent for crafting emotionally resonant pop songs. It remains a beloved love song that captures the ups and downs of romantic relationships.

32. Eye In the Sky – Alan Parsons Project

“Eye in the Sky” is a progressive rock and pop song by the Alan Parsons Project that explores the theme of surveillance and the power of the media. The song features Eric Woolfson’s ethereal vocals, Alan Parsons’ intricate production, and a haunting melody, creating a moody and atmospheric sound. The lyrics describe the feeling of being watched and monitored, capturing the paranoia and anxiety of modern society. The song was released in 1982 and became a hit, showcasing the Alan Parsons Project’s talent for crafting thought-provoking and musically adventurous songs. It remains a beloved classic that captures the spirit of the times.

33. Let’s Groove – Earth, Wind and Fire

“Let’s Groove” is a funk and R&B song by Earth, Wind & Fire that encourages listeners to dance and have fun. The song features Philip Bailey’s soaring vocals, a driving bass line, and a catchy chorus, creating an infectious and upbeat melody. The lyrics invite the listener to let go of their worries and enjoy the moment, capturing the spirit of the disco era. The song was released in 1981 and became a hit, showcasing Earth, Wind & Fire’s talent for crafting danceable and uplifting songs. It remains a beloved classic that gets people on their feet and grooving.

34. Open Arms – Journey

“Open Arms” by Journey is a classic power ballad that features soaring vocals and heartfelt lyrics about love and vulnerability. The song was written by Steve Perry and Jonathan Cain and became one of Journey’s biggest hits, reaching number two on the Billboard Hot 100. The song’s emotional resonance and lush instrumentation, including piano, guitar, and synthesizers, have made it a staple of romantic ballad playlists and a go-to for weddings and special occasions.

35. Leader of the Band – Dan Fogelberg

“Leader of the Band” by Dan Fogelberg is a moving tribute to Fogelberg’s father, a musician and bandleader who inspired his son’s love of music. The song’s gentle acoustic guitar and poignant lyrics capture the bittersweet nostalgia of looking back on a life filled with music and memories. Fogelberg’s tender vocals and intimate storytelling make “Leader of the Band” a timeless classic that celebrates the power of music to connect generations and touch our hearts.

36. Leather and Lace – Stevie Nicks and Don Henley

“Leather and Lace” by Stevie Nicks and Don Henley is a sultry duet that explores the complex dynamics of love and relationships. The song’s lyrics, which use the imagery of leather and lace to represent the contrasting personalities of the two singers, are at once sensual and vulnerable. Nicks and Henley’s voices blend seamlessly, creating a harmonious duet that captures the intensity of romantic attraction and the fear of losing oneself in love. The song’s haunting melody and intimate lyrics have made it a beloved classic of 80s soft rock.

37. Even the Nights Are Better – Air Supply

“Even the Nights Are Better” by Air Supply is a romantic ballad that captures the euphoria of falling in love. The song’s soaring vocals and lush orchestration, including strings and saxophone, create a dreamy, nostalgic atmosphere. Graham Russell’s lyrics celebrate the transformative power of love, offering a vision of a world where even the darkest nights are illuminated by the glow of true love. The song’s catchy melody and uplifting message have made it a beloved classic of 80s soft rock.

38. I’ve Never Been to Me – Charlene

“I’ve Never Been to Me” by Charlene is a deeply personal and introspective ballad that explores the search for meaning and fulfillment in life. The song’s soulful vocals and melancholic melody convey a sense of longing and yearning for something more. The lyrics, which describe the singer’s journey from fame and fortune to a life of emptiness and regret, offer a powerful message about the importance of finding one’s true self and following one’s own path. The song’s emotional honesty and raw vulnerability have made it a classic of 80s pop.

39. ’65 Love Affair – Paul Davis

“65 Love Affair” by Paul Davis is a nostalgic ode to a bygone era of innocence and romance. The song’s catchy melody and upbeat tempo, featuring a driving drumbeat and lively horns, capture the energy and optimism of youth. The lyrics, which describe a summer romance that burns bright and fades away, evoke a sense of wistful nostalgia for a time when love seemed simple and carefree. Davis’s smooth vocals and the song’s infectious groove have made it a beloved classic of 80s pop rock.

40. Heat of the Moment – Asia

“Heat of the Moment” by Asia is a high-energy rock anthem that captures the sound and spirit of 80s arena rock. The song’s soaring vocals and driving guitar riffs, accompanied by a pounding drumbeat, create a sense of urgency and excitement. The lyrics, which explore themes of passion and regret, offer a powerful message about the dangers of acting on impulse and the importance of self-control. The song’s catchy chorus and memorable hook have made it a beloved classic of 80s rock.

41. Take It Easy On Me – The Little River Band

“Take It Easy on Me” by The Little River Band is a soulful ballad that explores the complexities of relationships and the need for forgiveness. The song’s smooth vocals and gentle piano accompaniment, augmented by soaring harmonies and subtle guitar riffs, create a sense of intimacy and vulnerability. The lyrics, which describe a plea for understanding and compassion, offer a powerful message about the importance of empathy and kindness in relationships. The song’s emotional resonance and heartfelt delivery have made it a classic of 80s soft rock.

42. Pac Man Fever – Buckner and Garcia

“Pac-Man Fever” by Buckner and Garcia is a fun and playful tribute to the iconic video game of the same name. The song’s catchy melody and upbeat tempo, featuring synthesized video game sounds and a driving beat, capture the energy and excitement of gaming culture. The lyrics, which describe the addictive thrill of playing Pac-Man and other classic arcade games, evoke a sense of nostalgia for a bygone era of gaming. The song’s infectious groove and irreverent humor have made it a beloved classic of 80s pop culture.

43. That Girl – Stevie Wonder

“That Girl” by Stevie Wonder is a soulful, upbeat track from his 1982 album, “Original Musiquarium I.” With Wonder’s signature funk-infused sound, the song tells the story of a man who falls in love with a woman he meets at a party. Wonder’s vocals are passionate and energetic, while the instrumentation features a catchy bassline, horn section, and syncopated rhythms. The song’s chorus is infectious and easy to sing along to, making it a fan favorite and a testament to Wonder’s enduring legacy in R&B and soul music.

44. Private Eyes – Daryl Hall and John Oates

“Private Eyes” by Daryl Hall and John Oates is a pop rock classic from 1981. The song features the duo’s signature harmonies and catchy hooks, with lyrics about a private investigator who is always watching and keeping tabs on people. The song’s memorable opening keyboard riff and funky guitar riff make it instantly recognizable, and it became a massive hit for Hall and Oates, reaching number one on the Billboard Hot 100. “Private Eyes” remains a beloved classic of 80s pop and rock music, and a testament to Hall and Oates’ enduring influence.

45. Trouble – Lindsey Buckingham

“Trouble” by Lindsey Buckingham is a 1981 single from the Fleetwood Mac guitarist’s debut solo album, “Law and Order.” The song features Buckingham’s signature guitar work and layered vocals, with lyrics about the challenges of navigating life and relationships. The song’s chorus is soaring and anthemic, showcasing Buckingham’s ability to craft emotionally resonant melodies. “Trouble” was a top 10 hit on the Billboard Hot 100, and remains a fan favorite and a testament to Buckingham’s singular talent as a songwriter and musician.

46. Making Love – Roberta Flack

“Making Love” by Roberta Flack is a 1982 ballad from the singer’s album “I’m the One.” The song is a slow, sensual track featuring Flack’s smooth vocals and a lush orchestration of strings and piano. The lyrics are romantic and intimate, with Flack expressing her desire to make love to her partner. The song’s bridge features a soaring saxophone solo, adding to the song’s emotional impact. “Making Love” showcases Flack’s vocal prowess and her ability to create beautiful, heartfelt ballads that resonate with audiences.

47. Love’s Been a Little Bit Hard On Me – Juice Newton

“Love’s Been a Little Bit Hard On Me” by Juice Newton is a country pop hit from 1982. The song features Newton’s signature vocals, which are both powerful and vulnerable, with lyrics about the ups and downs of love. The song’s upbeat tempo and catchy chorus make it a fun, upbeat addition to any playlist, while the lyrics offer a relatable perspective on the challenges of romantic relationships. “Love’s Been a Little Bit Hard On Me” was a top 10 hit on the Billboard Hot 100, and remains a beloved classic of 80s country pop music.

48. Young Turks – Rod Stewart

“Young Turks” by Rod Stewart is a song that tells the story of two teenagers who leave their homes to pursue their dreams in the big city. The song is upbeat and catchy, with a driving rhythm and memorable chorus. It’s a celebration of youth and the spirit of adventure, with Rod Stewart’s distinctive vocals lending the track a sense of excitement and urgency. “Young Turks” remains a classic of the 80s rock era, capturing the sense of optimism and possibility that defined that decade.

49. Freeze-Frame – J. Geils Band

“Freeze-Frame” by J. Geils Band is a high-energy rock track with a catchy hook and a danceable beat. The song is built around a riff that combines guitar, saxophone, and synthesizer, creating a distinctive sound that’s instantly recognizable. The lyrics tell the story of a woman who’s constantly changing her mind and mood, with the chorus urging her to “freeze-frame” and make a decision. With its irresistible groove and infectious energy, “Freeze-Frame” is a classic of the early 80s and a staple of rock radio.

50. Keep the Fire Burnin’ – REO Speedwagon

“Keep the Fire Burnin'” by REO Speedwagon is a power ballad that showcases the band’s knack for crafting emotional and anthemic songs. The track features a soaring melody and heartfelt lyrics that speak to the power of perseverance and the importance of staying true to oneself. With its memorable chorus and strong vocal performance from lead singer Kevin Cronin, “Keep the Fire Burnin'” is a testament to the enduring power of classic rock ballads.

51. Do You Believe In Love – Huey Lewis and The News

“Do You Believe In Love” by Huey Lewis and The News is a pop-rock anthem that celebrates the joy and excitement of falling in love. The song features a catchy hook and a driving beat, with Huey Lewis’s distinctive vocals adding a touch of soulful energy to the proceedings. With its upbeat, optimistic message and infectious melody, “Do You Believe In Love” became a top 10 hit in the US and remains a beloved classic of the 80s.

52. Cool Night – Paul Davis

“Cool Night” by Paul Davis is a smooth, soulful ballad from the early 80s. The song starts with gentle piano chords and Davis’ silky voice, which sets a romantic mood. The lyrics describe the feelings of a man who is completely captivated by his lover, as he compares her beauty to the stars in the sky. The chorus is catchy and memorable, with a groovy bassline and melodic harmonies. The saxophone solo towards the end adds a jazzy touch to the song, making it perfect for a slow dance or a cozy night in. “Cool Night” is a timeless classic that will continue to enchant listeners for generations to come.

53. Caught Up In You – 38 Special

“Caught Up In You” by 38 Special is an upbeat rock song released in 1982. The song features catchy guitar riffs, a lively drum beat, and passionate vocals. It tells the story of a man who is caught up in the excitement and passion of a new relationship. He can’t stop thinking about his lover and is willing to do anything to keep the fire burning. The song was a commercial success and is considered a classic rock staple.

54. Why Do Fools Fall In Love – Diana Ross

“Why Do Fools Fall In Love” is a classic R&B song originally recorded by Frankie Lymon & the Teenagers in 1956. Diana Ross covered the song in 1981, giving it a new life with her soulful vocals and modern production. The song is about the inexplicable nature of falling in love, despite the risks and heartbreak that often come with it. The catchy chorus and upbeat melody make it a timeless classic that continues to be played on radio stations and in films.

55. Love In the First Degree – Alabama

“Love In the First Degree” by Alabama is a country-pop song that tells the story of a woman who is accused of a crime she did not commit, but is willing to serve time for it because she is in love with the man who committed it. The upbeat tempo and catchy chorus make it a fan-favorite, and the harmonies of the group add to the overall charm of the song.

56. Hooked On America – Royal Philharmonic Orchestra

“Hooked On America” by the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra is a patriotic instrumental that features recognizable American tunes such as “America the Beautiful,” “The Star-Spangled Banner,” and “Yankee Doodle.” The orchestra’s rendition of these classics is powerful and uplifting, inspiring pride in the listener for their country.

57. Wasted On the Way – Crosby, Stills and Nash

“Wasted On the Way” by Crosby, Stills and Nash is a melancholic ballad that speaks to the regret of missed opportunities and lost time. The harmonies and acoustic guitar work of the group create a peaceful and reflective atmosphere, and the lyrics encourage the listener to appreciate the present and not let it slip away.

58. Think I’m In Love – Eddie Money

“Think I’m In Love” is a catchy rock song by Eddie Money that features driving guitar riffs and a strong rhythm section. The track showcases Money’s gritty vocals and his ability to write a catchy hook. The lyrics describe the narrator’s feelings of uncertainty and confusion about whether he is in love or not. The song’s infectious melody and upbeat tempo make it a classic rock favorite.

59. Love Is In Control (Finger On the Trigger) – Donna Summer

“Love Is In Control (Finger On the Trigger)” is a disco track by Donna Summer that showcases her powerful vocals and the genre’s trademark electronic instrumentation. The song’s driving beat and catchy melody are complemented by Summer’s dynamic range and control. The lyrics describe the narrator’s sense of being swept away by love, and the idea that love has a life of its own. “Love Is In Control” is a classic example of Donna Summer’s ability to create infectious dance tracks.

60. Personally – Karla Bonoff

“Personally” is a heartfelt ballad by singer-songwriter Karla Bonoff. The song showcases Bonoff’s emotive vocals as she sings about the pain of letting go of a past love. The track features a soft, acoustic guitar and piano accompaniment that allows Bonoff’s voice to take center stage. The lyrics express the conflicting emotions of wanting to move on from the relationship while also feeling a sense of loss and longing. “Personally” is a poignant and introspective song that captures the complexity of human emotions.

61. One Hundred Ways (Find 100 Ways) – Quincy Jones

“One Hundred Ways” is a smooth R&B track by Quincy Jones featuring vocals from James Ingram. The song’s catchy melody and upbeat tempo are complemented by Ingram’s soulful vocals. The lyrics suggest a variety of ways to show someone love and affection, from sending flowers to writing love letters. The song’s message is one of romantic optimism and the belief that there are endless ways to express love. “One Hundred Ways” is a classic example of the timeless appeal of Quincy Jones’ productions.

62. Blue Eyes – Elton John

“Blue Eyes” is a tender love song by Elton John that showcases his piano skills and soulful voice. The track features a memorable melody and lyrics that describe the narrator’s love and admiration for a woman with blue eyes. The song’s romantic sentiments are expressed with sincerity and sensitivity, and the arrangement is simple yet elegant. “Blue Eyes” is a beautiful and timeless love song that has become a fan favorite in Elton John’s catalog.

63. Our Lips Are Sealed – The Go-Go’s

“Our Lips Are Sealed” is a catchy new wave track by The Go-Go’s that has become a classic of 80s pop. The song’s driving guitar riff and upbeat tempo are complemented by the group’s harmonized vocals. The lyrics describe a secret that the narrator shares with someone, but vows not to reveal. The song’s theme of keeping secrets is universal and relatable, and the catchy melody and sing-along chorus make it a memorable and fun track.

64. You Could Have Been With Me – Sheena Easton

“You Could Have Been With Me” is a synth-pop ballad by Sheena Easton that showcases her powerful vocals. The song’s catchy chorus and memorable melody are complemented by electronic instrumentation that is typical of the genre. The lyrics describe the narrator’s regret at not being able to be with someone she loves, and her hopes that they will be together in the future. “You Could Have Been With Me” is a heartfelt and emotional ballad that showcases Sheena Easton’s vocal range and versatility.

65. You Can Do Magic – America

“You Can Do Magic” by America is a pop rock song with upbeat instrumentation and a positive message of encouragement. The lyrics speak of the power of believing in oneself and achieving one’s dreams, using magical imagery to convey this idea. The song features catchy hooks, strong harmonies, and a lively guitar solo that add to its upbeat vibe. Released in 1982, it became a hit for America and remains a popular classic rock radio staple.

66. Did It In a Minute – Daryl Hall and John Oates

“Did It In a Minute” by Daryl Hall and John Oates is a funky pop song with a groovy bassline and a catchy chorus. The song’s lyrics describe a whirlwind romance that happened quickly but was intense and memorable. With its infectious melody and memorable hook, the song became a hit for the duo in 1982, and its funky sound continues to make it a fan favorite.

67. I Ran (So Far Away) – A Flock Of Seagulls

“I Ran (So Far Away)” by A Flock of Seagulls is a new wave/synth-pop classic from 1982 with a distinct, soaring synth melody and catchy chorus. The song’s lyrics describe a man who is on the run from a mysterious enemy, using the power of his legs to escape. The song’s iconic music video featuring the lead singer’s distinctive haircut became an MTV staple and helped propel the song to great success. It remains a beloved 80s anthem.

68. Somebody’s Baby – Jackson Browne

“Somebody’s Baby” by Jackson Browne is a soulful ballad about a man’s longing for a woman he sees walking down the street. The lyrics convey a sense of yearning and desire, as the singer imagines the woman’s life and wonders if he will ever have a chance to know her. With its smooth instrumentation and heartfelt vocals, the song became a hit for Browne in 1982, and it remains a timeless classic.

69. Oh No – The Commodores

“Oh No” by The Commodores is a soulful, mid-tempo ballad with lush instrumentation and romantic lyrics. The song’s narrator expresses his love for a woman and pleads with her not to leave him. With its smooth vocals, jazzy piano, and tender lyrics, the song became a hit for the Commodores in 1981 and remains a popular slow jam today.

70. Take It Away – Paul McCartney

“Take It Away” by Paul McCartney is an upbeat pop-rock song from his 1982 album “Tug of War.” The song features McCartney’s signature catchy melodies, tight harmonies, and energetic guitar riffs. The lyrics are about seizing the moment and taking action to make things happen, encouraging listeners to “take it away” and follow their dreams. The song also features a catchy chorus with McCartney’s trademark “oh-oh-oh” vocals that make it a memorable and fun sing-along tune.

71. It’s Gonna Take a Miracle – Deneice Williams

“It’s Gonna Take a Miracle” by Deniece Williams is a soulful R&B ballad that was a hit in the 1980s. The song features Williams’ powerful vocals and emotional delivery, as she sings about the challenges of finding true love and how it will take a miracle to make it happen. The song also features a lush production with a full orchestra and background choir that adds to the drama and intensity of the song. With its heartfelt lyrics and stirring melodies, “It’s Gonna Take a Miracle” is a classic love song that continues to resonate with listeners today.

72. A Love Song – Kenny Rogers

“A Love Song” by Kenny Rogers is a romantic ballad that was released in 1982. The song features Rogers’ warm and smooth vocals, accompanied by gentle acoustic guitar and piano. The lyrics are about the joy and happiness that love can bring, and the promise to cherish and love someone forever. The song is a testament to Rogers’ ability to deliver heartfelt, emotional ballads that tug at the heartstrings and leave a lasting impression on listeners.

73. Don’t Stop Believin’ – Journey

“Don’t Stop Believin'” by Journey is a classic rock anthem that has become an iconic song since its release in 1981. The song features a driving beat, soaring vocals, and catchy guitar riffs that make it an instant crowd-pleaser. The lyrics are about the power of perseverance and the need to keep pushing forward, no matter what obstacles stand in the way. The song has been used in countless movies, TV shows, and sporting events, and has become a timeless classic that continues to inspire and motivate listeners of all ages.

74. Comin’ In and Out of Your Life – Barbra Streisand

“Comin’ In and Out of Your Life” by Barbra Streisand is a poignant ballad that was released in 1981. The song features Streisand’s powerful vocals and emotional delivery, as she sings about the ups and downs of a relationship that is never quite meant to be. The lyrics are about the pain of loving someone who can never fully commit, and the struggle to move on and let go. The song is a masterclass in storytelling and emotional expression, and Streisand’s voice brings a depth and richness to the song that makes it unforgettable.

75. Gloria – Laura Branigan

“Gloria” by Laura Branigan is an upbeat pop song that features powerful vocals and a catchy chorus. The song is about a woman named Gloria who is looking for love and is determined to find it. With its energetic instrumentation and Branigan’s dynamic voice, “Gloria” became an instant classic and a popular dance track in the 1980s.

76. Empty Garden (Hey, Hey Johnny) – Elton John

“Empty Garden (Hey, Hey Johnny)” by Elton John is a touching tribute to John Lennon, who was assassinated in 1980. The song mourns the loss of the musician and his impact on the world, and also touches on the theme of gun violence. With its poignant lyrics and John’s emotive piano playing, “Empty Garden” is a heartfelt and somber tribute to a beloved artist.

77. Yesterday’s Songs – Neil Diamond

“Yesterday’s Songs” by Neil Diamond is a nostalgic ballad that reflects on the past and the memories that come with it. The song speaks to the idea that even though time passes and things change, the memories of the past remain vivid and important. Diamond’s rich voice and sentimental lyrics make “Yesterday’s Songs” a timeless classic.

78. Crimson and Clover – Joan Jett and The Blackhearts

“Crimson and Clover” by Joan Jett and The Blackhearts is a rock song that features a distinctive guitar riff and Jett’s signature raw vocals. The song’s lyrics are somewhat cryptic, but seem to speak to the power of love and the intensity of emotions. “Crimson and Clover” has become a classic rock staple, thanks to its memorable hook and Jett’s powerhouse performance.

79. Every Little Thing She Does Is Magic – The Police

“Every Little Thing She Does Is Magic” by The Police is a poppy, upbeat love song that celebrates the joy of falling in love. The song’s lyrics express the singer’s admiration for his partner and the way that she makes him feel. With its catchy melody and Sting’s smooth vocals, “Every Little Thing She Does Is Magic” is a romantic and feel-good tune that continues to be popular today.

80. Here I Am (Just When I Thought I Was Over You) – Air Supply

“Here I Am (Just When I Thought I Was Over You)” by Air Supply is a soft rock ballad about a person who thought they had moved on from a past love, only to find themselves still deeply affected by them. With its emotional lyrics and soaring vocals, the song showcases Air Supply’s signature sound and has become a classic love ballad.

81. I Keep Forgettin (Every Time You’re Near) – Michael Mcdonald

“I Keep Forgettin (Every Time You’re Near)” by Michael McDonald is a smooth R&B track that features McDonald’s soulful vocals and a funky groove. The song’s lyrics speak to the singer’s inability to resist the pull of an ex-lover, even though he knows he should. “I Keep Forgettin” is a timeless tune that has been covered by numerous artists and continues to be a popular song today.

82. Get Down On It – Kool and The Gang

“Get Down On It” by Kool and The Gang is a funky dance track that encourages listeners to let loose and have a good time. With its catchy hook and upbeat rhythm, the song became an instant party classic and has remained popular over the years. “Get Down On It” showcases Kool and The Gang’s skill at blending funk, pop, and R&B into a sound that appeals to a wide audience.

83. Any Day Now – Ronnie Milsap

“Any Day Now” by Ronnie Milsap is a country ballad that speaks to the pain of waiting for a love that may never come. The song’s lyrics are poignant and emotive, and Milsap’s rich voice adds to the song’s emotional impact. “Any Day Now” has become a beloved classic in the country music canon and continues to touch the hearts of listeners.

84. Make a Move On Me – Olivia Newton-John

“Make a Move On Me” by Olivia Newton-John is an upbeat pop song that encourages the object of the singer’s affection to take action and make a move. With its catchy chorus and Newton-John’s sweet vocals, the song is a fun and flirty anthem that showcases the singer’s pop sensibilities. “Make a Move On Me” has become a beloved classic in the world of 80s pop music.

85. Take My Heart (You Can Have It if You Want It) – Kool and The Gang

“Take My Heart (You Can Have It if You Want It)” by Kool and The Gang is a funk classic from the 80s. The song’s groovy bassline and catchy chorus make it a dancefloor favorite. The lyrics express the singer’s willingness to give his heart to the woman he loves and the desire for her to take it. The song features smooth vocals and energetic instrumental breaks, showcasing Kool and The Gang’s signature sound. “Take My Heart” was a big hit in the 80s and remains a beloved classic to this day, capturing the spirit of funk and soul of that era.

86. Mirror, Mirror – Diana Ross

“Mirror, Mirror” by Diana Ross is a soulful ballad about heartbreak and self-reflection. The song talks about a woman who looks at herself in the mirror and wonders what went wrong in her relationship. She questions her decisions and actions, wondering if she could have done things differently. The lyrics are powerful and emotional, and Ross’s vocals are both haunting and beautiful.

87. Vacation – The Go-Go’s

“Vacation” by The Go-Go’s is a fun and upbeat song about getting away from it all. The song talks about the excitement of going on vacation and leaving your worries behind. The catchy melody and sing-along chorus make it a perfect summer anthem. The Go-Go’s were one of the most successful all-female bands of the 80s, and “Vacation” is one of their biggest hits.

88. (Oh) Pretty Woman – Van Halen

Van Halen’s cover of “Oh Pretty Woman” is a hard rock rendition of Roy Orbison’s classic song. The guitar riffs are powerful and energetic, and David Lee Roth’s vocals add a touch of humor and fun to the song. The lyrics talk about a man who sees a beautiful woman and can’t resist her charms. The song became one of Van Halen’s biggest hits and is still a popular classic rock tune.

89. Should I Do It – Pointer Sisters

“Should I Do It” by Pointer Sisters is an upbeat disco song about a woman who is unsure about whether she should pursue a relationship with a man. The lyrics are playful and flirty, and the disco beat is infectious. The Pointer Sisters were known for their catchy dance tunes, and “Should I Do It” is no exception.

90. Hot In the City – Billy Idol

“Hot In the City” by Billy Idol is a synth-heavy rock song that captures the energy and excitement of New York City. The lyrics talk about the fast-paced lifestyle and the thrill of living in the city. The song’s driving beat and catchy chorus make it a popular dance tune, and Idol’s trademark snarl adds a touch of rebellion to the song. “Hot In the City” is one of Billy Idol’s biggest hits and remains a popular classic rock song.

91. Kids in America – Kim Wilde

“Kids in America” by Kim Wilde is a classic new wave anthem about youth culture and rebellion. The song’s catchy chorus and upbeat melody make it a fun and energetic tune. The lyrics celebrate the freedom and excitement of being young and living life to the fullest. “Kids in America” was a big hit in the 80s and is still a popular song today.

92. Man On Your Mind – The Little River Band

“Man On Your Mind” by The Little River Band is a soft rock ballad about a man who is in love with a woman who is already in a relationship. The song’s gentle melody and heartfelt lyrics capture the pain and longing of unrequited love. The Little River Band was known for their easy-listening hits in the 70s and 80s, and “Man On Your Mind” is one of their most popular songs.

93. What’s Forever For – Michael Murphy

“What’s Forever For” by Michael Murphy is a country-pop ballad that explores the meaning of love and commitment. The song’s poignant lyrics ask whether love can last forever or whether it’s just a fleeting feeling. The gentle melody and Murphy’s soulful vocals make it a touching and emotional tune. “What’s Forever For” was a big hit in the early 80s and remains a beloved country classic.

94. Waiting On a Friend – The Rolling Stones

“Waiting On a Friend” by The Rolling Stones is a laid-back rock tune that captures the spirit of friendship and camaraderie. The song’s mellow melody and Keith Richards’ signature guitar riffs make it a relaxing and enjoyable listen. The lyrics talk about waiting for a friend and the joy of spending time together. “Waiting On a Friend” was a big hit in the 80s and is still a popular classic rock song today.

95. All I Do – Stevie Wonder

“All I Do” by Stevie Wonder is a soulful and funky love song that showcases Wonder’s smooth vocals and signature sound. The song’s catchy chorus and upbeat melody make it a fun and enjoyable listen. The lyrics express the joy and passion of being in love and the desire to spend every moment with that special someone. “All I Do” is one of Wonder’s most popular hits and a beloved soul classic.

96. Working for the Weekend – Loverboy

“Working for the Weekend” by Loverboy is an 80s rock classic with an upbeat, high-energy sound. The lyrics convey the universal feeling of looking forward to the weekend, and the desire to let loose and have fun after a hard week’s work. The catchy chorus and driving guitar riffs make it a popular party anthem that still resonates with listeners today.

97. Goin’ Down – Greg Guidry

“Goin’ Down” by Greg Guidry is a smooth and soulful track with a funky groove. The song features a distinctive bassline and catchy horn section, as well as Guidry’s smooth vocals. The lyrics tell the story of a man who’s fallen on hard times and is trying to pick himself up again, while also acknowledging the struggles of others in the same boat.

98. Arthur’s Theme (Best That You Can Do) – Christopher Cross

“Arthur’s Theme (Best That You Can Do)” by Christopher Cross is a soft rock classic from the 80s, featuring smooth vocals and a gentle melody. The lyrics express the idea that life is what you make of it, and that even in tough times, you can still find joy and meaning. The song’s memorable chorus and beautiful piano and saxophone solos make it a timeless classic.

99. Through the Years – Kenny Rogers

“Through the Years” by Kenny Rogers is a romantic ballad that celebrates the ups and downs of a long-lasting relationship. Rogers’ smooth vocals and the song’s gentle melody make it a perfect slow dance track. The lyrics express gratitude for the love and support of a partner, and the idea that a strong relationship is built over time, through both good times and bad.

100. Edge of Seventeen – Stevie Nicks

“Edge of Seventeen” by Stevie Nicks is a powerful and anthemic rock track that showcases Nicks’ distinctive voice and poetic lyrics. The song’s driving guitar riffs and pounding drums make it a classic rock staple, while the lyrics express a sense of resilience and determination in the face of adversity. Nicks wrote the song in memory of her uncle, and the lyrics reflect both her grief and her determination to keep going.
